Marathon medical tent anticipates busy day

With high temps and inexperienced runners, the medical tent will likely be one of the busiest places along the Marathon route.

  • video Runners ready for heat

  • Photos
    Starting line in Hopkinton
  • Photos
    The fast and the famous
  • Photos
    Events over the weekend
  • Photos
    Marathon expo scenes
The men's lead pack went through two miles in 9:42, with American Glenn Randall of Mesa, Co. running well in front, followed by American Nicholas Arciniaga of Flagstaff, Ariz. Globe Staff Photo / Yoon S. Byun
The elite men took off from the starting line in Hopkinton around 10 a.m. Following right behind them are the 9,000 runners of both sexes who make up Wave One. Globe Staff Photo / Zuri Berry
The elite women took off from the starting line in Hopkinton around 9:30 today and set a slow pace in the heat. The defending champion is 31-year-old Caroline Kilel of Kenya. Globe Staff Photo / Pat Greenhouse
The wheelchair race began in Hopkinton around 9:15 this morning. About 15 minutes later, the elite women runners took off from the starting line. Globe Staff Photo / Yoon S. Byun
Sue Kwan (left) and Tony Jang waited calmly in the athlete's village in Hopkinton. Marathon officials said runners should treat today as an experience, not a race. Globe Photo / Brian Feulner
Jeff Zaucha stretched before the start of the Marathon in Hopkinton. Race director Dave McGillivray told runners that with today's heat, it's "not a day to set a personal record." Globe Photo / Brian Feulner
Michele Curley got her number pinned on by Maureen Jones before the start of the 2012 Boston Marathon in the athlete's village in Hopkinton. Globe Photo / Brian Feulner
Carrying a sign that read, "Sweat is sexy," watchers gathered near the start of the Boston Marathon in Hopkinton to cheer on runners. Globe Staff Photo / Zuri Berry
From left: Christian Thorn, Michael Santos, and Bryan Delaney of AMI Graphics affixed the starting line signs in Hopkinton this morning ahead of the 116th Boston Marathon. Globe Staff Photo / Yoon S. Byun

Red Sox vs. Rays | 11 a.m.

Kevin Youkilis out of today's lineup, responds to Bobby Valentine's criticism

Youkilis said he was "confused" by the comment he's not as "into the game as he has been in the past." He's also not in today's lineup. (Globe, 8:51 a.m.)

Early history on display in Lexington

Today's Battle of Lexington Green reenactment took place very early, and spectators set their alarms to arrive in time to hear the first shots -- just before 6 a.m. (Globe, 8:20 a.m.)

Mass. millionaires want tax increases

Some of the nation’s wealthiest people, including a handful from the Bay State, are asking the government to raise their taxes under the “Buffett Rule.’’ (Boston Globe)

In Greenland, N.H., healing prayers

In church Sunday morning, parishioners prayed for the police chief killed and the four other police officers wounded in last week's shocking police shooting. (Globe)

Mortgage aid helps more hold off default

More financially stressed homeowners are getting mortgage loan modifications that cut their payments enough to keep them from falling into foreclosure. (Globe)

Years later, school may
alert parents to abuse

The operators of the Trivium School say they are considering notifying parents and alumni about the 2009 conviction of the Rev. Donald J. McGuire for molesting a former student.

Casino bid sparks tribal turf fight

The Pocasset Wampanoag is accusing the Mashpee Wampanoag of elbowing into what was historically Pocasset land in picking Taunton for a proposed casino.

Boston Marathon’s senior surge

A record 596 runners age 65 and older have registered to compete today, 47 of whom are age 75 and older.
opinion | Adrian Walker

Vince Wilfork’s worthy cause

The Patriots star has used his fame and fortune to raise money and awareness for diabetes research, a disease that has taken a toll on his own family.

Bertucci’s seeks new customer base

After 31 years, Bertucci’s is courting a new, youthful clientele in an effort known within the company’s headquarters as ‘‘The Millennial Project.’’

AVEO set to bring first drug to market

AVEO Pharmaceuticals plans to apply for federal approval of its first drug, for kidney cancer, and is set to add 120 new employees in 2012.

Rallies highlight fracture in Tea Party

An apparent rift between Mass. Tea Party activists over whether to put a focus on social issues played out at separate rallies in Worcester and in Boston.

Historic Boston walking tour

Welcome to Boston.com's GPS tour of historical sites in Boston. The city is full of history, and it's a city that is easily seen on foot. This historic walk is a relatively quick and easy way to visit a number of historic sites in the downtown area.
